verses.text: The sons of Reuben, Israel's firstborn. He was the firstborn, but because he defiled his father's bed, his birthright was given to the sons of Joseph, son of Israel. So the genealogy is not listed according to birthright.
verses.comment: Explanation of Reuben’s loss of the birthright due to his sin; maintains emphasis that genealogy doesn't follow birth order.

verses.text: Though Judah was strong among his brothers and a ruler came from him, the birthright belonged to Joseph.
verses.comment: Clarifies distinction—rulership from Judah, birthright to Joseph.

verses.text: The sons of Reuben, Israel's firstborn: Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi.
verses.comment: Direct list of Reuben’s sons; matches original names.

verses.text: The sons of Joel: Shemaiah his son, Gog his son, Shimei his son,
verses.comment: Genealogy continues with Joel; names unaltered.

verses.text: Micah his son, Reaiah his son, Baal his son,
verses.comment: Continued genealogy; note Baal as personal name here.

verses.text: Beerah his son, who was taken into exile by Tiglath-Pileser king of Assyria; he was leader of the Reubenites.
verses.comment: Beerah is mentioned as an exile; identifies historical context.

verses.text: His brothers by their clans, as listed in their genealogies by lineage: the chief, Jeiel, Zechariah,
verses.comment: Genealogical records for Reuben’s relatives.

verses.text: and Bela son of Azaz, son of Shema, son of Joel—living in Aroer, as far as Nebo and Baal-meon.
verses.comment: Places associated with Reuben’s clan; names preserved.

verses.text: Eastward he settled as far as the edge of the wilderness that extends to the Euphrates River, because their livestock had increased in the land of Gilead.
verses.comment: Notes reasons for territorial expansion; livestock detail kept.

verses.text: In the days of Saul, they waged war against the Hagrites, who fell into their hands. They lived in their tents throughout the entire region east of Gilead.
verses.comment: Historical note about war with Hagrites.

verses.text: The sons of Gad lived next to them in Bashan till Salecah:
verses.comment: Records Gad location and geographical extent.

verses.text: Joel was chief, Shapham second, then Jaanai and Shaphat in Bashan.
verses.comment: Order of leadership among Gadites.

verses.text: Their relatives by families: Michael, Meshullam, Sheba, Jorai, Jacan, Zia, and Eber, seven in all.
verses.comment: Direct list of relatives; maintains original order and count.

verses.text: These were the sons of Abihail son of Huri, son of Jaroah, son of Gilead, son of Michael, son of Jeshishai, son of Jahdo, son of Buz.
verses.comment: Genealogy traced precisely as in original.

verses.text: Ahi son of Abdiel, son of Guni, was head of their clans.
verses.comment: Names unchanged; ‘head of clans’ for clarity.

verses.text: They lived in Gilead, in Bashan and its towns, and throughout all pasturelands of Sharon to their very limits.
verses.comment: Expanded locations covered by Gadites.

verses.text: All these were registered in genealogies during the reigns of Jotham king of Judah and Jeroboam king of Israel.
verses.comment: Historic context for registration; clarified names.

verses.text: The sons of Reuben, Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh—valiant men, men who carried shield and sword, skilled with bow, trained for war—forty-four thousand seven hundred sixty able to go to battle.
verses.comment: List of warriors and weaponry noted for clarity.

verses.text: They fought against the Hagrites, Jetur, Naphish, and Nodab.
verses.comment: Enemy clans listed as per original.

verses.text: They received help against them, for they cried out to God in the battle, and he granted their request because they trusted in him.
verses.comment: Emphasizes answer to prayer and trust in God.

verses.text: They captured their livestock—fifty thousand camels, two hundred fifty thousand sheep, and two thousand donkeys—as well as one hundred thousand people.
verses.comment: Exact numbers maintained as stated in original.

verses.text: For many fell slain, because the battle was from God. And they lived in their place until the exile.
verses.comment: Notes divine intervention and period of settlement.

verses.text: The half-tribe of Manasseh lived in the land from Bashan to Baal-hermon, Senir, and Mount Hermon. They were numerous.
verses.comment: Clarifies Manasseh’s territory.

verses.text: These were their chiefs: Epher, Ishi, Eliel, Azriel, Jeremiah, Hodaviah, and Jahdiel—mighty warriors, men of renown, heads of their clans.
verses.comment: List follows original; titles adjusted for clarity.

verses.text: But they were unfaithful to the God of their fathers and prostituted themselves to the gods of the peoples of the land, whom God had destroyed before them.
verses.comment: ‘Prostituted’ language kept to reflect gravity of apostasy.

verses.text: So the God of Israel stirred the spirit of Pul king of Assyria, and Tiglath-Pileser king of Assyria, and he carried them away—the Reubenites, Gadites, and half-tribe of Manasseh—to Halah, Habor, Hara, and the river of Gozan, to this day.
verses.comment: Maintains all place and ruler names. End phrase ‘to this day’ matches eternal witness in original.
